title: I miss the tribunal
body:
Riot, why did you hire an intern to write the bots that "review" reports? Why can't you see that literally every game that employs this tactic fails dramatically? From what I gather, insulting yourself is bannable, swearing at no one in particular is bannable, play the game and saying report the obviously-feeding teammate is bannable, playing the darn GAME is bannable. 

I miss when ACTUAL PEOPLE reviewed report incidents and judged them fairly, unlike the bots you now employ so that you can save money by not paying more of your employees (KDA Akali, cough cough). 

Your game is toxic because every move you make enables and encourages toxicity. 

I just love the theory that, if someone is picking on you/tormenting you/making your life hell, that's fine. You're ALLOWED to defend yourself... by asking them nicely to stop. Heaven forbid you defend yourself or quote what they said. 

League has become the most toxic game online, and you lot wonder why.

Also, go ahead and downvote me, as everyone who complains about the ban system seems to get.. You'll see what I mean when you get that one rando who decides to int and feed, then report YOU for asking why they are doing that.

Bots, no matter how well written, dont understand context reliably. Shit, _humans_ seem to fail horribly at such advanced mental arts as sarcasm, correctly deducing context, or recognizing irony.

In general, there is no reason to do any of those things, and a lot of extremely toxic players hide behind excuses of humor or "just playing around". 

If you received a punishment that you think is in error, feel free to post logs or send a support ticket to dispute it. Most of the time OP just turns out to be a delusional, entitled brat, and not the recipient of an erroneous punishment.

Have you seen "The Matrix"? (spoilers ahead)

At the end of the film, after Neo 'dies' and comes back. The agents fire bullets at him, which NEO stops in mid-air. Agent Smith attempts to punch him multiple times and Neo begins blocking all the punches. Neo even turns 90Â° and begins blocking all of Smith's attacks with one hand, effortlessly. Eventually NEO tires of the game, and sends Agent Smith flying with a swift and powerful kick.

Wouldn't it be great, if a bully was attacking you, if you could actively block or deflect every single punch? Every single attack? Without ever hitting back? The 'real world' doesn't work like the matrix, unless you've studied martial arts your entire life (maybe not even then). But LEAGUE can work like this. NEO dying is like that first barrage of toxicity. But then, you just hit the MUTE button and now you're like NEO coming back, stopping bullets, and effortlessly BLOCKING all incoming attacks. That's 'true' DEFENSE. 

You might point out that our hero NEO gets to fight back with that wicked Lee Sin kick that sends Agent Smith careening down the hall, and Neo ultimately wins the fight and continues on to the sequels. And you'd be right. And YOU get to do that too! REPORT that offending player. That's the kick. It'll up their chances of being punished. That's winning the fight.

Like Agent Smith and NEO, you and the toxic player will probably be back for the sequels (i.e. playing more games of league). But in our example NEO is the hero and Agent Smith eventually loses, even when he makes multiple smurf accounts of himself. :D

But the real red pill isn't calling people snowflakes or SJWs, or growing a thick skin, or being an 'alpha', or any of the other crap that people post about on the interwebz. The real red pill is learning to harness the power within to be the best 'you' that you can be.

Be Neo.

This isn't how schools work. If you have a legitimate fear of bodily injury and you punch somoene back, you won't be punished.

**However** if you punch someone just because they made you mad or sad or bullied you, then yeah, you're going to be punished - it was unnecessary.
Have you been to public schools? I can absolutely guarantee you that that's how they work.

Not only have I been to a public school, I went to a 6A school in Texas (one of the largest), and actually was involved in a situation like you describe.

I was not punished in any way, shape, or form.

You are imposing what you **want** to believe on what is the actual truth - and it's not. You do not get to just claim things are true because they suit your argument.

No offense, but you also don't get to claim that my situation is UNtrue just because you have not experienced it yourself either. You've been to a school where they were fair, I can see that. I'm happy for you. But I've been to plenty of schools (we moved every half year) that actively refuse to do anything until they see the retaliation. If they don't see the bully throw a punch back (or see the first hit), you're the only one that gets punished. I've lived it too.

Look, this is going to be harsh, so prepare:

Have you considered that **you** may have been the instigator in these fights you're remembering? You have the sort of combative "defensive" attitude on here and in League that it seems very likely to me (I have a degree in psychology, before you ask what my credentials are) that you yourself were the one blowing these interactions out of proportion, and it was **your** fault that the situation escalated into physical violence. You're claiming that you see people getting punished from these situations.. but in fact in cases where that's happened there has been outrage in local, if not national news, and the cases have been reversed. Go back to 2008-2012 timeframe and you'll see lots of outrage and reversals of school punishment in local news all across the country.

Even so, this situation really doesn't apply to League - there's literally no physical harm, damage, or injury that can come to you in League, thus it doesn't matter what schools do - that's a debate for another day.

Hey this may seem harsh too:

Maybe a degree in psych doesn't mean that you can discern a person's personal history based solely upon a few posts they make online in one night after being frustrated for, at least what seems to him, unfair punishment. 

But yes, you found me out. I was the orchestrator of all of my hardships. Excuse me while I go and reflect on this revelation.

In response to all of the mute recommendations: I don't think muting someone is a very good solution. This does not prevent this person from harassing your team, or the other team, and turning them against you. They most likely can, and will continue to point out every mistake you make to turn your team against you. League has no way to leave a game without being punished, so it isn't even like you can leave. Muting is simply a band-aid that most likely won't save you. Someone being harassed really has few options to stop it other than waiting and hoping their report matters. It can be frustrating, in fact, I hardly chat at all in league for that reason, I don't want to risk getting banned over something silly. Just my thoughts on the mute solution, take it as you will.

> This does not prevent this person from harassing your team, or the other team, and turning them against you. They most likely can, and will continue to point out every mistake you make to turn your team against you. 

...okay.  And if you are not saying anything back (mostly because I don't have a clue what the toxic person is typing), who cares if everyone turn against you?  If I play the next 100 games and I get reported by 900 players, I bet you my account I will not see a single punishment or warning or any kind (I know how the IFS and feederbuster work well enough).  I chat almost every single game.  The only time I don't chat is when I am sleepy, tired, or otherwise in a bad mood.  I've been playing since Season 3.  Normal, non-toxic people have very little fear of chatting.

As someone with honor level 5 and no reports to my knowledge, I know I got there by just taking the abuse. By "taking the high road" and letting people shit on me. Just saying, I sympathize when someone can't take it anymore and says something. I just ignore them as everyone suggests, but that doesn't make it feel any better. It feels worse, you feel powerless. Maybe you don't care if your whole team is against you but other people might. Not many people want to be in a team where they don't feel wanted or appreciated, or at least tolerated. However, I feel like muting the offending player would simply leave me clueless as to what slander they may be spreading.

How exactly do people abuse you if you cannot see what they are saying?  /fullmute
Why do you care what slander they are spreading?  The chance of you ever meeting that person again (unless you are master+ tier or something) is extremely small.  Even if you see that person again next game, dodge penalty is but a mere slap on the wrist.  And I go back to, why do you care what lies toxic people are spreading?  Simply mute everyone and play the game in silence.  It's not that hard. 

If you feel muting is not enough, what exactly do you want Rito to do?  Ban the player on the spot and turn the game 4v5?  And after the game, you can report that person and if you need confirmation people getting banned left and right for toxicity, read this board.

I meet assholes in real life almost every day of the week.  People who cut me off in traffic.  People who talk/laugh loudly in the movie theater.  People who disturb other people's meals by thinking they are at home with their friends and shout obscene jokes at each other, etc.  I simply move on with my days.

I can tell you that I did not get these by taking any kind of abuse.  Mute, report, move on.  I will lose 40-60% of all games I play.  One game of troll is simply part of that 40-60% loss ratio.  It's not a big deal.  If everyone is muted, I don't really care what they have to say.

https://i.imgur.com/E5OtBE4.png

As stated above, they can still abuse you by abusing your team and tilting them as well. It is less direct, but that does not mean it doesn't happen. Why play online games if you're simply muting everyone all the time? Part of a multiplayer game is experiencing it with other people. I'm not sure what would be a better solution, I will admit that, but muting should not be the only solution. Just because I do not have a better solution, does not make yours flawless.

But now I am curious, in your daily life how do you get over those things like traffic and people who talk in movies? Do you simply try to tune it out? Do you pretend the car cutting you off doesn't exist and rear end them?  Do you get a refund for your movie and leave? How do you do the equivalent of muting these things in real life?

I don't mute everyone.  I've only used /fullmute maybe 4,5 times.  I generally only single mute the flamer.  I enjoy chatting.  I chat with team and enemy almost every game unless I'm in a foul mood.  I am saying if you feel you are being abused by your team, then /fullmute them.  Muting is not a flawless solution.  But until you can come up with a better than, then it is the most viable solution and you should use it to its fullest.

I commute long distance daily.  People driving recklessly and cutting me off is just simply a part of my life.  Ignore and move on.  People talk in movies?  Go talk to the manager.  Getting into a shouting match with them just mean there are now 2 assholes who talk loudly in the movie.

> Riot, why did you hire an intern to write the bots that "review" reports?

Pretty sure Tantram (and whomever else may have had a hand in creating the IFS) is more than just an intern. Call it a hunch, but when the guy has a full blown title and actively works on the IFS, he's probably beyond the point of being trained.

> Why can't you see that literally every game that employs this tactic fails dramatically?

Got a list?

> From what I gather, insulting yourself is bannable, swearing at no one in particular is bannable, play the game and saying report the obviously-feeding teammate is bannable, playing the darn GAME is bannable.

The first is unnecessary, and yes, it can be punishable (since even self-directed negativity can lower team morale), the second is false, the third is unnecessary and also punishable (since consistently rallying for reports can be considered harassment), and the last is a poor use of hyperbole.

> I miss when ACTUAL PEOPLE reviewed report incidents and judged them fairly, unlike the bots you now employ so that you can save money by not paying more of your employees (KDA Akali, cough cough).

Whenever people chalk up the introduction of the IFS (which has been around for a while now, by the way) to greed and cutting costs, I have a hard time taking it seriously.

D'you know why the Tribunal got iceboxed and replaced with the IFS? Because it was slow, unreliable, and couldn't be incentivized without risking people just spamming "punish" for easy rewards.

It was unpopular enough that some people were getting punishments _months_ after they committed the offense, and not only that, it built up a massive backlog to boot.

And how, pray tell, do you think the IFS' judgements are unfair? Can you provide at least five examples of unfair punishments, or are you just assuming it's unfair because of a few posts making baseless claims and not providing their chat logs?

> Your game is toxic because every move you make enables and encourages toxicity.

And your proof of this is...?

> I just love the theory that, if someone is picking on you/tormenting you/making your life hell, that's fine. You're ALLOWED to defend yourself... by asking them nicely to stop. Heaven forbid you defend yourself or quote what they said.

You don't even need to ask them nicely to stop. Hell, you don't even need to ask them at all.

Y'know what you do?

**_Mute, report, move on._**

Not a word to them, and you can shut them out easily. And reporting them makes sure that they get punished for picking on you.

As for defending yourself - provide an example where someone actually defended themselves, and didn't retaliate. 'Cause that's a distinction to note; _Self-defense_ and _retaliation_ are two different things.

And as for quoting what they said; _if you are being bullied by someone, if someone is being rude to you, and you know that they're breaking the rules, **what good does it do you to quote the lines that are in breach of the rules?**_

If that resulted in a permanent ban, the player would have to have a storied history of previous toxicity, and thus is being held to a higher standard. Absence other kind of toxicity, general swearing will never result in punishment.

I have seen someone permed for calling themselves a %%%, with no other toxicity.

Zero-tolerance stuff requires little or no previous record for the system to shit a brick and smash the ban button. Players _should_ be aware, but some seem to think the rules dont apply or have weird loopholes.

You may ask why that is not allowed, but it comes down to loopholes. If you allow that sort of speech in specific situations, it just invites a legion of pedantic little shits to try and argue why their offensive usage should fall under the protected conditions.

That word isn't a swear. It's a slur.

**Swearing** at noone (i.e. the use of the words: fuck shit damn bitch ass, etc.) will **never** result in a ban simply for using that word. **Slurs** will result in a ban regardless of who they're directed at.
The fact remains that they were still punished for something that's supposedly not punishable.
That's the intern that coded the report-bot for you!

Feel free to write an AI that can discern context in conversation. It will make you a billionaire near-instantly and solve one of the biggest challenges of the industry.

Oh, what am i saying? You dont know a bloody thing about AI or software.
I don't need to be an artist to know bad art when I see it.

Bad art is subjective. A bad system is subjective. They are called opinions. You are entitled to yours, but you are not uniquely qualified to judge the merits of the system, any more than the rest of us. Your experiences in life do not make you an expert in any way, shape, or form.
Too bad this is logical and scientific engineering with hard rules and limits, not art.

That analogy doesn't work.

For one, it's not art. Art is completely different to coding. Art has you see everything there is in the picture; coding has numerous rules and logic systems working that you can't see, and you only get to see a select few outputs.

And, that leads into the second part of why your analogy doesn't work: You don't see it. Everything that you'd _have_ to see to be able to understand it and know whether it's good or bad is stuff _you can't see_.

And lastly, you may not need to be an artist to know bad art, but you kinda do need to have a degree of understanding of coding to know faulty code when you see it. And even then, what you think is faulty code may not actually be the problem, and troubleshooting has to go through, and...Y'get the picture.

So saying, "Damn I'm really bad" is a bannable offense?
GG riot. This is a new level low for you.

Makes a whole lot of sense. They were cursing us out, calling us bad, and feeding, but sure. He reports me and I get punished because I quoted them. Makes a whole lot of sense.

If someoneâs bothering you, mute them and report after the game is over. Itâs not your job to convince other players that a problem player is in the wrong are wrong and you are innocent. Just donât engage with them, thereâs no point, and it doesnât make the game more enjoyable for anyone. 

But as an aisise, âdamn Iâm so trashâ probably wouldnât result in any punishment. But similar to above, saying it really doesnât add anything to game experience so why bother anyway?

Yes. Muting them prevents them from feeding in a ranked game, prevents them from KSing, and prevents them from talking to the enemy team about how bad you are. That solves EVERYTHING. Why did no one think of this before?

Sorry, I think sarcasm is a form of harassment too according to the bot.
